claim: Electronics have become more affordable in the US since 1990.

supporting.text: The cost of manufacturing electronics has decreased significantly due to advancements in technology and economies of scale, making them more affordable.

attacks.text: The cost of manufacturing electronics has decreased significantly due to advancements in technology and economies of scale, making them more affordable.
While manufacturing costs have decreased, retail prices may not reflect this due to inflation, tariffs, or corporate profit margins.
Inflation-adjusted data shows that electronics prices have still fallen significantly despite nominal price fluctuations.
Some high-end electronics (e.g., flagship smartphones) have actually increased in price due to added features and brand premiums.
The average consumer now purchases mid-range devices where price declines are most evident, not flagship models.

supporting.text: The introduction of global supply chains and competition among manufacturers has driven down prices of consumer electronics over time.

attacks.text: The introduction of global supply chains and competition among manufacturers has driven down prices of consumer electronics over time.
Inflation-adjusted prices for some high-end electronics (e.g., flagship smartphones) have actually increased due to added features and premium branding.
Recent supply chain disruptions (e.g., semiconductor shortages) have caused price spikes, contradicting the long-term trend.
Flagship models represent a small fraction of the electronics market, where budget and mid-range devices dominate unit sales at lower prices.
Supply chain disruptions are temporary anomalies that don't negate the decades-long deflationary trend in electronics.

supporting.text: Inflation-adjusted prices for common electronics like televisions, computers, and smartphones have consistently dropped since 1990.

attacks.text: Inflation-adjusted prices for common electronics like televisions, computers, and smartphones have consistently dropped since 1990.
While prices for some electronics have dropped, essential components like semiconductors have seen price increases due to supply chain disruptions.
Supply chain disruptions are temporary and do not negate the long-term trend of falling prices for finished electronics.
The drop in prices does not account for hidden costs like mandatory software subscriptions or reduced product lifespans.
Hidden costs are not unique to electronics and are often offset by the increased functionality of modern devices.
The affordability claim ignores income stagnation for many Americans, making electronics relatively less affordable despite lower prices.
Income stagnation affects all goods, not just electronics, and the price drops still represent increased affordability in absolute terms.

supporting.text: The proliferation of budget-friendly electronics brands and models has expanded access to affordable options for consumers.

attacks.text: The proliferation of budget-friendly electronics brands and models has expanded access to affordable options for consumers.
Inflation-adjusted prices for many essential electronics (e.g., smartphones, laptops) have remained stable or increased due to premium features driving up costs.
Entry-level versions of these devices have indeed become cheaper, offsetting premium market trends.
Supply chain disruptions and semiconductor shortages post-2020 have caused price spikes, reversing prior affordability trends.
These disruptions are temporary and don't negate the long-term downward price trend since 1990.

supporting.text: Technological advancements have reduced the cost of components such as semiconductors, contributing to lower overall prices for electronics.

attacks.text: Technological advancements have reduced the cost of components such as semiconductors, contributing to lower overall prices for electronics.
Inflation-adjusted prices for some high-end electronics have remained stable or increased due to added features and branding.
Even with added features, the cost per unit of computing power or functionality has still decreased significantly.
Supply chain disruptions and trade tariffs have increased costs for certain electronic components in recent years.
These disruptions are temporary and don't negate the long-term trend of decreasing costs due to technological progress.

supporting.text: The used and refurbished electronics market has grown, providing more affordable alternatives to new products.

attacks.text: The used and refurbished electronics market has grown, providing more affordable alternatives to new products.
Refurbished electronics often have shorter lifespans and higher failure rates, reducing their cost-effectiveness.
Many refurbished products come with warranties and certifications, making them nearly as reliable as new ones.
The growth of the used electronics market is concentrated in high-income areas, limiting accessibility for lower-income consumers.
Online marketplaces and shipping have made used electronics accessible nationwide, not just in high-income areas.
